wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup: 11/21/2014
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top articles from around the industry so that you can stay up-to-date on the state of employee engagement in CSR and sustainability on the go.

Report: Sustainability Leaders Gaining Ground in Global Boardrooms

According to a new report by Verdantix, sustainability leaders have increasing influence, decision-making authority, strategy, and budgetary control. Encouraging results show that as many as 92% of sustainability leaders report directly to the CEO or executive committee and over two thirds expect corporate-wide spending growth. The report provides yet more proof of C-Suite support for sustainability initiatives across 21 industries.

How to sell a culture of sustainability

The leading takeaway: Change the conversation from how to make the business case for sustainability’ to how sustainability supports the business.’ Key strategies from the Greenbuild Conference and Expo on how to sell sustainability effectively within organizations for upper management and teams. For upper management, connect the initiatives with the organizations overall success. For teams, connect sustainability initiatives to their individual success.

7 Reasons HR Technology Is So Hot Today

Bersin by Deloitte, recently published new research on HR technology buying trends, finding: 57% of companies plan to make a major new HR software purchase in the next 18 months. So what’s leading this massive growth? Among the seven reasons identified in the article, the top three include: current HR software systems are aging, Cloud HR software is now easy to buy, and new platforms offer better user interfaces.

To End Food Waste, Change Needs to Begin At Home

Food waste in the U.S. is a big problem: 20% of what goes into municipal landfills is food, and 40 – 50% of food waste comes from consumers, with the remaining 50 – 60 % coming from business. Clearly this is a big problem, but what’s motivating is that it’s something everyone can help solve at home and at work. In fact, we found that 89% of people would try a sustainability tactic at home introduced at work, suggesting home and work-based actions are self-reinforcing.

NRG Seeks to Cut 90% of Its Carbon Emissions

NRG broke industry news by announcing that it aims to reduce carbon emissions 50% by 2030 and 90% by 2050. This is a big move for the leading electricity company, considering NRG made its name originally from coal and other conventional power plants. Since 2005, the company has already reduced its carbon emissions by 40%–a leading example of best practice for the industry and a promising sign for the future of power production.
